title: The Silent Protestor
description: Ravi, a college student, stood silently outside the university gate holding a blank placard. He didn't shout slogans or block anyone. The university suspended him for 'creating disturbance'. Ravi argues his peaceful protest is protected.
explanation: Silent protest is a form of expression protected under Article 19(1)(a). Combined with the right to peaceful assembly under Article 19(1)(b), Ravi's actions were constitutional. The suspension was unjustified.
whyItMatters: Freedom of expression includes non-verbal forms of protest. Citizens can peacefully dissent without facing arbitrary punishment.

title: The Denied Tenant
description: Priya, a single working woman, was refused a rental apartment by the landlord who said, 'We don't rent to single women - it's against our family values.' Priya claims this is discrimination.
explanation: Article 15 prohibits discrimination on grounds of sex. While fundamental rights primarily apply against the State, various housing laws and the spirit of equality extend these protections against discriminatory practices.
whyItMatters: Discrimination based on gender in housing affects women's independence and dignity. Constitutional values must permeate society.

title: The Child Worker
description: A 12-year-old boy works at a local tea stall. The owner says, 'His family needs money, and he's learning a skill.' The boy works 8 hours daily and doesn't attend school.
explanation: Article 24 prohibits employment of children below 14 in hazardous occupations. Article 21A guarantees right to education for children aged 6-14. Both rights are being violated here.
whyItMatters: Child labor robs children of education and childhood. The Constitution prioritizes children's welfare over economic arguments.

title: The Journalist's Source
description: A journalist publishes a story exposing government corruption based on leaked documents. The government demands she reveal her source, threatening arrest. She refuses, citing press freedom.
explanation: Freedom of press is implicit in Article 19(1)(a). Protection of journalistic sources is essential for press freedom and public interest reporting. Courts have upheld this principle.
whyItMatters: A free press is democracy's watchdog. Protecting sources enables journalists to expose wrongdoing without fear.

title: The Religious Loudspeaker
description: A temple uses loudspeakers at 4 AM daily for prayers. Nearby residents complain about noise pollution and disturbed sleep. The temple claims it's their religious right.
explanation: While Article 25 guarantees freedom of religion, it's subject to public order, morality, and health. Using loudspeakers causing noise pollution violates others' right to peaceful living under Article 21.
whyItMatters: Religious freedom doesn't include the right to disturb others. Rights must be balanced with responsibilities to the community.

title: The Quota Question
description: A state government reserves 70% of government jobs for backward classes. A general category candidate challenges this, arguing it leaves too few opportunities for others.
explanation: While Article 16(4) allows reservation for backward classes, the Supreme Court (Indra Sawhney case) capped total reservation at 50%. Exceeding this limit violates equality principles.
whyItMatters: Reservation promotes social justice but must balance with equality of opportunity. The 50% ceiling maintains this balance.

title: The Detained Activist
description: An activist critical of the government is arrested and held for 15 days without being told why or being produced before a magistrate. Police say it's for 'national security'.
explanation: Article 22 mandates that every arrested person must be informed of grounds of arrest and produced before a magistrate within 24 hours. Vague 'national security' claims don't override this protection.
whyItMatters: Protection against arbitrary detention is fundamental to liberty. Even suspected criminals deserve due process.

title: The School's Dress Code
description: A government school bans students from wearing any religious symbols or attire, including hijabs, turbans, and religious threads. Students from multiple communities protest this uniform policy.
explanation: Article 25 protects religious practices. While reasonable uniform policies are allowed, blanket bans on all religious symbols disproportionately affect religious freedom. Courts examine if restrictions are reasonable.
whyItMatters: Religious identity is deeply personal. Policies must balance institutional needs with individual religious freedom.

title: The Minimum Wage Worker
description: A construction company pays workers ₹150/day when the state minimum wage is ₹350/day. The company argues workers 'agreed' to this wage and are free to leave if unhappy.
explanation: Paying below minimum wage constitutes economic exploitation under Article 23. Article 21's right to life includes the right to livelihood with dignity. 'Consent' under economic duress isn't valid consent.
whyItMatters: The Constitution protects workers from exploitation. Economic vulnerability doesn't strip away fundamental protections.

title: The Viral Video
description: Someone posts a video criticizing a political leader using satire and humor. The government orders the video removed and files a case against the creator for 'hurting sentiments'.
explanation: Political satire is protected speech under Article 19(1)(a). Criticism of public figures, even through humor, is essential in a democracy. 'Hurt sentiments' alone doesn't justify restricting speech.
whyItMatters: Democracy thrives on open debate and criticism. Satire has historically been a powerful tool for political commentary.
